[**Key Concepts (videos)**]{.teal-text .body-text-m}

These short videos that accompany *Mastering ’Metrics* are a great resource for Chapter-1. The style is a bit extra, but they explain the key concepts clearly. If any of these concepts are unclear, I strongly recommend watching them (they may be relevant to the reading quiz tomorrow):

- [Ceteris Paribus & Counterfactuals - 6 minutes](https://mru.org/courses/mastering-econometrics/ceteris-paribus)
- [Ommitted Variable Bias & Selection Bias - 9 minutes](https://mru.org/courses/mastering-econometrics/selection-bias)
- [Experimental Design & Random Assignment - 10 minutes](https://mru.org/courses/mastering-econometrics/introduction-randomized-trials)
- [How to Read Econometrics Papers - 12 minutes](https://mru.org/courses/mastering-econometrics/how-read-economics-research-papers-randomized-controlled-trials-rcts)

[**References**]{.teal-text .body-text-m}

- [Gelman, A., & Loken, E. (2013) ](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Cx2fqgKDTzMQjXtyo4Cz2YK4dQQzpb4Z/view?usp=drive_link){target="_blank"}. *The garden of forking paths: Why multiple comparisons can be a problem, even when there is no “fishing expedition” or “p-hacking” and the research hypothesis was posited ahead of time.* Department of Statistics, Columbia University, 348(1-17), 3.
- [Buntaine, M. T., Komakech, P., & Shen, S. V.
